title.en: Biographies of Lord Pingyuan and Yu Qing
title.raw: 《平原君虞卿列傳》 Biographies of Lord Pingyuan and Yu Qing

sentences.zh: 平原君趙勝者，趙之諸公子也。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan, Zhao Sheng, was one of the noble scions of Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan, whose name was Zhao Sheng, was one of the noble princes of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 諸子中勝最賢，喜賓客，賓客蓋至者數千人。

translations.literal: Among the noble scions, Sheng was the most worthy. He delighted in guests, and the number of guests who came to him reached several thousand.
translations.idiomatic: Among the princes, Sheng was considered the most worthy. He delighted in hospitality, and the guests who flocked to him numbered in the thousands.

sentences.zh: 平原君相趙惠文王及孝成王，三去相，三復位，封於東武城。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan served as chancellor to Kings Huiwen and Xiaocheng of Zhao. Three times he resigned the chancellorship, three times he was restored to office, and he was enfeoffed at Dongwu City.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan served as Chancellor to Kings Huiwen and Xiaocheng of Zhao. Three times he stepped down from the chancellorship, and three times he was restored to his post. He was eventually enfeoffed at Dongwu City.

Ping Yuan Jun chancellor Zhao Hui Wen Wang and Xiao Cheng Wang, three leave chancellor, three restore position, enfeoff at east Wu city.

sentences.zh: 平原君家樓臨民家。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan's house tower overlooked a commoner's home.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan’s residence featured a tower that overlooked the homes of commoners.

sentences.zh: 民家有躄者，槃散行汲。

translations.literal: In the commoner's home lived a crippled man who, with his knees spread apart, crawled to draw water.
translations.idiomatic: In one of those homes lived a crippled man who walked with great difficulty whenever he went to draw water.

sentences.zh: 平原君美人居樓上，臨見，大笑之。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan's concubine was dwelling in the tower above, looked down and saw him, and burst out laughing.
translations.idiomatic: One of Lord Pingyuan’s concubines, looking down from the tower, saw him and burst into laughter.

sentences.zh: 明日，躄者至平原君門，請曰：「臣聞君之喜士，士不遠千里而至者，以君能貴士而賤妾也。

translations.literal: Tomorrow, cripple arrive Ping Yuan Jun gate, request: Minister hear jun happy scholar, scholar not far thousand li arrive, with jun can noble scholar cheap concubine.
translations.idiomatic: The next day, the crippled man came to Lord Pingyuan's gate and made this request: 'I have heard that Your Lordship delights in worthy men. Worthy men travel thousands of li without hesitation to reach you, because you honor the worthy and humble the unworthy.

sentences.zh: 臣不幸有罷癃之病，而君之後宮臨而笑臣，臣願得笑臣者頭。」

translations.literal: Alas, I suffer from a debilitating illness. Yet one of Your Lordship's concubines looked down upon me and laughed. I wish to have the head of the one who laughed at me.'
translations.idiomatic: "It is my misfortune to suffer from this debilitating ailment. Yet one of your lordship’s concubines looked down and mocked me. I wish to have the head of the one who laughed at me."

sentences.zh: 平原君笑應曰：「諾。」

translations.literal: Ping Yuan Jun laugh respond: Yes.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan laughed and replied, 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 躄者去，平原君笑曰：「觀此豎子，乃欲以一笑之故殺吾美人，不亦甚乎！」

translations.literal: Cripple go, Ping Yuan Jun laugh: View this young child, then wish with one laugh reason kill my beauty, not also extreme!
translations.idiomatic: The crippled man departed, and Lord Pingyuan laughed, saying: 'Look at this wretched fellow! He wants to kill my beautiful concubine just because of a single laugh. Isn't this going too far!'

sentences.zh: 終不殺。

translations.literal: In the end, he did not kill her.
translations.idiomatic: In the end, however, he could not bring himself to kill her.

sentences.zh: 居歲餘，賓客門下舍人稍稍引去者過半。

translations.literal: More than a year passed, and gradually more than half of the retainers in his household had departed.
translations.idiomatic: After about a year, more than half of the retainers and guests in his household had gradually drifted away.

sentences.zh: 平原君怪之，曰：「勝所以待諸君者未嘗敢失禮，而去者何多也？」

translations.literal: Ping Yuan Jun strange, say: Sheng so wait various jun not dare lose ritual, leave why many?
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan was puzzled and said: 'I, Sheng, have never dared to treat you gentlemen discourteously. Why have so many departed?'

sentences.zh: 門下一人前對曰：「以君之不殺笑躄者，以君為愛色而賤士，士即去耳。」

translations.literal: Gate below one person before answer: With jun not kill laugh cripple, with jun love color cheap scholar, scholar then leave.
translations.idiomatic: One of his retainers stepped forward and replied: 'Because Your Lordship did not kill the concubine who laughed at the cripple, they think you value beauty over worth. The worthy men have departed.'

sentences.zh: 於是平原君乃斬笑躄者美人頭，自造門進躄者，因謝焉。

translations.literal: Thereupon Lord Pingyuan had the concubine who laughed at the cripple beheaded. He personally went to the gate and invited the cripple in, then apologized to him.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon, Lord Pingyuan had the concubine who had laughed at the cripple beheaded. He personally went to the man's door to present the head and offer his apologies.

sentences.zh: 其後門下乃復稍稍來。

translations.literal: Afterward, his retainers gradually began to return once more.
translations.idiomatic: Afterward, his retainers gradually began to return to him.

translations.literal: At this time, Qi had Lord Mengchang, Wei had Lord Xinling, and Chu had Lord Chunshen. Thus they vied with one another to attract worthy men with generous treatment.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Qi had Lord Mengchang, Wei had Lord Xinling, and Chu had Lord Chunshen; all of them vied with one another to attract and maintain worthy men.

translations.literal: When Qin besieged Handan, Zhao sent Lord Pingyuan to seek aid. He allied with Chu and brought along twenty of his retainers who possessed both martial valor and literary accomplishment.
translations.idiomatic: When Qin besieged Handan, Zhao sent Lord Pingyuan to seek aid and form an alliance with Chu. He planned to take twenty of his retainers who were accomplished in both civil and military arts.

sentences.zh: 平原君曰：「使文能取勝，則善矣。

translations.literal: Ping Yuan Jun say: Make literary can take win, then good.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan said: 'If diplomacy can secure victory, that would be excellent.

sentences.zh: 文不能取勝，則歃血於華屋之下，必得定從而還。

translations.literal: If diplomacy cannot prevail, then we shall perform the blood oath beneath the ornate hall and secure a firm alliance before returning.'
translations.idiomatic: "If diplomacy fails to secure victory, then we shall take a blood oath beneath their grand hall, for I am determined to return only after the alliance is sealed."

sentences.zh: 士不外索，取於食客門下足矣。」

translations.literal: We shall not seek worthy men from outside; those among my retainers will suffice.'
translations.idiomatic: "We need not search for worthy men elsewhere; those among my own retainers will be sufficient."

sentences.zh: 得十九人，餘無可取者，無以滿二十人。

translations.literal: They obtained nineteen men, but there were no others worthy of selection, so they could not fill the twentieth position.
translations.idiomatic: He found nineteen men, but among the rest, none were worthy of selection, and so he could not fill the twentieth position.

translations.idiomatic: Among his retainers was a man named Mao Sui. He stepped forward and recommended himself to Lord Pingyuan, saying: 'I, Sui, have heard that Your Lordship will form a vertical alliance with Chu, bringing along twenty of your retainers, seeking none from outside.

sentences.zh: 今少一人，願君即以遂備員而行矣。」

translations.literal: Now you lack one man. I wish Your Lordship would immediately include me, Sui, to complete the number and depart.'
translations.idiomatic: "Now that you are short one man, I hope your lordship will allow me to fill that vacancy and accompany you."

sentences.zh: 平原君曰：「先生處勝之門下幾年於此矣？」

translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan said: 'Sir, how many years have you been dwelling in my household?'

sentences.zh: 毛遂曰：「三年於此矣。」

translations.idiomatic: Mao Sui replied: 'Three years now.'

sentences.zh: 平原君曰：「夫賢士之處世也，譬若錐之處囊中，其末立見。

translations.literal: Ping Yuan Jun say: Worthy scholar dwell world, like awl dwell bag middle, its point immediately see.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan said: 'Truly, when a worthy man dwells in the world, it is like an awl placed in a bag - its point immediately becomes visible.

sentences.zh: 今先生處勝之門下三年於此矣，左右未有所稱誦，勝未有所聞，是先生無所有也。

translations.literal: Now you have dwelt in my household for three years, yet no one on my left or right has ever praised or quoted you. I have never heard of you. This means you have no talent at all.
translations.idiomatic: "You have been in my household for three years now, yet I have never heard any of my attendants praise you, nor have I seen any proof of your ability. This suggests you have no particular talent."

sentences.zh: 先生不能，先生留。」

translations.literal: If you cannot do it, sir, then stay behind.'
translations.idiomatic: "Since you lack the necessary merit, sir, you should stay behind."

sentences.zh: 毛遂曰：「臣乃今日請處囊中耳。

translations.literal: Mao Sui say: Minister then today request dwell bag middle.
translations.idiomatic: Mao Sui replied: 'Your servant is only today requesting to be placed in the bag.

sentences.zh: 使遂蚤得處囊中，乃穎脫而出，非特其末見而已。」

translations.literal: If I had been placed in the bag earlier, I would have burst forth like the tip of an awl - not merely showing its point, but protruding completely.'
translations.idiomatic: "Had I been placed in the bag sooner, the point of my awl would have pierced through completely, rather than just showing its tip!"

translations.literal: In the end, Lord Pingyuan brought Mao Sui along.
translations.idiomatic: In the end, Lord Pingyuan allowed Mao Sui to accompany him.

translations.literal: The nineteen others exchanged glances and smiled at him, but did not reject him.
translations.idiomatic: The nineteen other men exchanged amused glances, but they did not openly reject him.

translations.literal: When Mao Sui arrived in Chu, he debated with the nineteen others, and all nineteen submitted to him.
translations.idiomatic: By the time they reached Chu, Mao Sui had debated with the nineteen others, and they were all won over by his reasoning.

sentences.zh: 平原君與楚合從，言其利害，日出而言之，日中不決。

translations.literal: Lord Pingyuan negotiated the vertical alliance with Chu, discussing its advantages and disadvantages. They began speaking at sunrise, but by noon had reached no decision.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Pingyuan discussed the merits and risks of the alliance with the King of Chu; though they began their talks at sunrise, by noon they had still reached no decision.

sentences.zh: 十九人謂毛遂曰：「先生上。」

translations.literal: Nineteen people tell Mao Sui: Mister ascend.
translations.idiomatic: The nineteen others said to Mao Sui: 'Sir, you go up.'

sentences.zh: 毛遂按劍歷階而上，謂平原君曰：「從之利害，兩言而決耳。

translations.literal: Mao Sui press sword climb steps ascend, tell Ping Yuan Jun: Vertical profit harm, two words decide.

translations.idiomatic: We began speaking of the alliance at sunrise, yet by noon we have reached no decision. Why is this?'

translations.idiomatic: Mao Sui advanced, gripping his sword, and said: 'Your Majesty rebukes me because of Chu's great multitude.

sentences.zh: 今十步之內，王不得恃楚國之眾也，王之命縣於遂手。

translations.literal: Within these ten paces, Your Majesty cannot rely on Chu's multitude. Your life hangs by my hand.
translations.idiomatic: "Within these ten paces, Your Majesty cannot rely on the strength of Chu’s armies. Your life hangs by my hand alone."

sentences.zh: 吾君在前，叱者何也？

translations.idiomatic: My lord stands before you. Why do you rebuke me?

translations.literal: Moreover, I have heard that Tang became king of the world with seventy li of land, and King Wen made the feudal lords his subjects with a hundred li of territory. Was it because they had many soldiers? It was because they knew how to seize the moment and exert their authority.
translations.idiomatic: "Furthermore, I have heard that Tang ruled the world with only seventy li of land, and King Wen made the lords his subjects with but a hundred li. It was not because their soldiers were numerous, but because they understood how to wield their position and exert their authority."

sentences.zh: 今楚地方五千里，持戟百萬，此霸王之資也。

translations.literal: Now Chu territory spans five thousand li, with a million halberdiers; these are the resources of a hegemon.
translations.idiomatic: "Today, Chu spans five thousand li and commands a million spears; these are the resources of a true hegemon."

sentences.zh: 以楚之彊，天下弗能當。

translations.literal: With the strength of Chu, the world cannot withstand it.
translations.idiomatic: "With the strength of Chu, no one in the world should be able to withstand you."

sentences.zh: 白起，小豎子耳，率數萬之眾，興師以與楚戰，一戰而舉鄢郢，再戰而燒夷陵，三戰而辱王之先人。

translations.literal: Bai Qi was merely a minor servant, yet he led several tens of thousands of troops to battle Chu. In one battle he took Yan and Ying, in the second he burned Yiling, and in the third he disgraced Your Majesty's ancestors.

sentences.zh: 此百世之怨而趙之所羞，而王弗知惡焉。

translations.literal: This is a grudge for a hundred generations and a shame to Zhao, yet Your Majesty does not know to be revolted by it.
translations.idiomatic: "This is a grievance that should last a hundred generations and a shame that even Zhao feels on your behalf, yet Your Majesty does not seem to feel the sting of it."

sentences.zh: 合從者為楚，非為趙也。

translations.idiomatic: "This alliance is for the benefit of Chu, not merely for Zhao."

sentences.zh: 虞卿既以魏齊之故，不重萬戶侯卿相之印，與魏齊閒行，卒去趙，困於梁。

translations.literal: Yu Qing, because of Wei Qi's matter, did not value the seal of a marquis of ten thousand households or the position of chancellor. He secretly traveled with Wei Qi, finally left Zhao, and was distressed in Liang.
translations.idiomatic: Because of his friendship with Wei Qi, Yu Qing set aside the seal of a marquis of ten thousand households and the rank of high minister. He traveled in secret with Wei Qi and eventually left Zhao, only to find himself in dire straits in Liang.

sentences.zh: 魏齊已死，不得意，乃著書，上採春秋，下觀近世，曰節義、稱號、揣摩、政謀，凡八篇。

translations.literal: After Wei Qi died and Yu Qing did not achieve his ambitions, he wrote a book, drawing from the Spring and Autumn Annals above and observing the recent world below, entitled Sections on Righteousness, Appellations, Assessment, and Political Strategy, in all eight scrolls.
translations.idiomatic: After Wei Qi died and Yu Qing found no other way to fulfill his ambitions, he began to write. Drawing inspiration from the *Spring and Autumn Annals* of old and observing the events of the modern world, he composed eight chapters on topics such as 'Integrity and Duty,' 'Appellations,' 'Assessment,' and 'Political Strategy.'

sentences.zh: 以刺譏國家得失，世傳之曰虞氏春秋。

translations.literal: It criticized and satirized the gains and losses of states, and the world transmitted it as the Yu Family Spring and Autumn Annals.
translations.idiomatic: His work critiqued the successes and failures of states, and it has been handed down to the world as the *Yu Family Spring and Autumn Annals*.

translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: Lord Pingyuan was a fine nobleman of graceful bearing in this troubled age, yet he did not perceive the larger picture.

sentences.zh: 鄙語曰「利令智昏」，平原君貪馮亭邪說，使趙陷長平兵四十餘萬眾，邯鄲幾亡。

translations.idiomatic: As the vulgar saying goes, 'Profit blinds the intellect.' Lord Pingyuan, greedy for Feng Ting's treacherous advice, caused Zhao to lose 400,000 troops at Changping, bringing Handan to the brink of destruction.

translations.idiomatic: Yu Qing assessed situations and gauged feelings, devising strategies for Zhao - how skillful he was!
